entry.et: Middle English, from Old English mǣst; akin to Old High German meist most, Old English māra more more

def.dt: :greatest in quantity, extent, or degree the most ability
:the majority of most people
:to the greatest or highest degree often used with an adjective or adverb to form the superlative the most challenging job he ever had
:to a very great degree was most persuasive
:the greatest amount it's the most I can do
:as an extreme limit took him an hour at most

entry.fl: pronoun, singular or plural in construction

def.dt: :the greatest number or part most become discouraged and quit
:almost we'll be crossing the river most any time now Hamilton Basso

entry.pt: Although considered by some to be unacceptable in all cases, most is often used to mean “almost” in both spoken and, to a lesser extent, written English to modify the adjectives all, every, and any; the pronouns all, everyone, everything, everybody, anyone, anything, and anybody; and the adverbs everywhere, anywhere, and always. Other uses of this sense of most are dialectal.

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English manig; akin to Old High German manag many, Old Church Slavic mŭnogŭ much

def.dt: :consisting of or amounting to a large but indefinite number worked for many years
:being one of a large but indefinite number many a man many another student
:the same in number saw three plays in as many days

entry.et: Middle English muche large, much, from michel, muchel, from Old English micel, mycel; akin to Old High German mihhil great, large, Latin magnus, Greek megas, Sanskrit mahat

def.dt: :great in quantity, amount, extent, or degree there is much truth in what you say taken too much time
:great in importance or significance nothing much happened
:many in number
:more than is expected or acceptable :more than enough the large pizza is a bit much for one person
:wonderful exciting
:terrible awful
:to a great degree or extent :considerably much happier
:very much gratified
:frequently often
:by or for a long time didn't get to work much before noon
:by far was much the brightest student
:nearly approximately looks much the way his father did
:the same in quantity not quite as much money
:to the same degree

entry.et: Middle English, alteration of -mest (as in formest foremost)

def.dt: :most innermost :most toward headmost

dt.un: used as a title for an archbishop or a Roman Catholic bishop
